payload.name: narrative-causal-storytelling
payload.core: Build coherent time-ordered explanations connecting events, motives, and causes into a story that supports prediction and action. Integrates causal chains, actor intentions, and temporal sequence into persuasive explanations. Output is a communicable narrative, not a validated causal model—use for explanation and alignment, not for causal proof.

out.d: timestamped sequence of key events with source attribution; gaps marked explicitly
actors + attributed intentions + evidence basis for each attribution
directed graph: event_A -> event_B with link type (enabled/triggered/accelerated) and confidence (high/medium/low)
prose account integrating timeline, motives, and causes; includes 'story thesis' sentence
list of gaps, assumptions, and low-confidence links explicitly flagged
>=1 plausible counter-story with key divergence point identified

proc: CHRONICLE: enumerate events from sources; timestamp each; mark source reliability (primary/secondary/inferred); flag gaps with '?' marker
SEQUENCE: order events chronologically; identify parallel threads; note sequencing uncertainties
ACTORS: list agents with roles; attribute motives only with cited evidence (quote, action, statement); mark speculative attributions
LINK: for each adjacent event pair, state link type (enabled/triggered/accelerated/coincident) and confidence; if confidence <medium, mark as assumption
SYNTHESIZE: draft narrative with explicit 'thesis' (one sentence stating the story's causal claim); weave events, motives, links
STRESS-TEST: generate >=1 alternative narrative from same events; identify the 'fork point' where interpretations diverge
REGISTER: compile uncertainty register; list every gap, assumption, low-confidence link, and speculative motive
check: every event has timestamp (or explicit 'unknown') and source
motive attributions cite evidence, not intuition
causal links have explicit type and confidence level
>=1 alternative narrative documented with fork point
uncertainty register is non-empty (no story is complete)
narrative does not claim causal proof—only explanation

diff.abductive: narrative builds full arc with actors and timeline; abductive generates single best explanation for specific observations without temporal/actor structure
diff.causal-inference: narrative prioritizes coherence and communicability; causal-inference validates via intervention, conditioning, or statistical test—use after narrative to verify claims
diff.rhetorical: narrative explains what happened and why; rhetorical persuades audience to act—narrative supplies content, rhetorical shapes delivery
diff.mechanistic: narrative is actor-centric (who did what); mechanistic is process-centric (how the system behaves)—combine when actors operate within systems
diff.historical-investigative: narrative synthesizes into story; investigative prioritizes evidence triangulation and source critique—investigative is more skeptical, narrative more constructive
diff.sensemaking: narrative explains a specific event sequence; sensemaking builds general interpretive frame for a class of situations

confusions.symptom: stakeholder asks 'did X cause Y?' and you respond with a story instead of a testable causal claim
confusions.correction: if the goal is causal proof, use causal-inference (mode 37) with intervention or conditioning; narrative is for explanation and communication, not validation

confusions.symptom: treating narrative coherence as evidence of truth; omitting source critique
confusions.correction: investigative mode prioritizes evidence triangulation; narrative mode prioritizes communicable story—if evidence is contested, run investigative first, then narrative

confusions.symptom: building detailed story before knowing what kind of situation this is
confusions.correction: if the situation type is unclear, use sensemaking (mode 63) to establish frame first; narrative assumes the frame is already known

fail.desc: Narrative feels complete and inevitable; alternative explanations seem implausible; the story writes the evidence rather than evidence writing the story
signals: story has no gaps or uncertainties—everything fits perfectly
alternative narratives dismissed in <1 sentence or not considered
hindsight bias: 'of course this happened, it was inevitable'
inconvenient facts omitted or footnoted rather than integrated
motive attributions feel obvious but lack cited evidence
narrative closure achieved before evidence review complete

mitigations.m: document >=1 alternative narrative with explicit fork point
mark every motive attribution with evidence type (quote/action/inference)
mitigations.test: no motive in actor_motive_map lacks evidence_type field

mitigations.m: assign confidence to each causal link; flag >=1 as low/medium
mitigations.test: causal_chain contains at least one link with confidence != 'high'

mitigations.m: state what evidence would falsify the narrative thesis
have second reader identify the most 'convenient' fact; justify its inclusion
time-box synthesis to prevent polish hiding gaps
mitigations.test: synthesis drafted before 60% of time budget; remainder for stress-test

use: executive briefings on complex event sequences
root cause communication (after causal analysis complete)
retrospectives where shared understanding matters more than precision

rel.r: generates candidate explanations; narrative extends into full story arc
validates causal claims narrative asserts; use after narrative to test
shapes delivery of narrative content for persuasion
provides process-level detail within narrative actor actions
tests 'what if' against narrative to identify pivotal moments
establishes situation frame before narrative construction

ex.sit: Postmortem: Production outage lasted 4 hours. Engineering and leadership need aligned understanding.
steps: CHRONICLE: deploy 14:00 (CI log), alerts 14:15 (PagerDuty), war room 14:30 (Slack), rollback 18:00 (deploy log); gap: no data 14:15-14:30
SEQUENCE: deploy -> [15 min gap] -> alerts -> war room -> rollback; parallel: customer complaints 14:20-17:00
ACTORS: Dev team (pushed deploy under deadline pressure—cited: sprint review notes); SRE (delayed escalation—cited: Slack silence 14:15-14:30); PM (set deadline—cited: roadmap doc)
LINK: deploy->alerts [triggered, high]; deadline->skipped load test [enabled, medium]; cache bypass->DB overload [triggered, high]
SYNTHESIZE: Thesis: Deadline pressure led to skipped load test, which masked a cache dependency that caused cascading DB failure. [full narrative prose follows]
STRESS-TEST: Alt narrative: SRE delay was primary cause—if escalation at 14:15, rollback by 15:00. Fork point: was 14:15-14:30 delay decisive?
REGISTER: gaps: 14:15-14:30 activity unknown; assumptions: deadline pressure caused skip (correlation, not proof); low-confidence: PM deadline was binding vs advisory
ex.insight: narrative exposes systemic cause (deadline pressure) beyond proximate cause (bad code); alternative narrative surfaces SRE process gap for separate follow-up

micro_ex.sit: Customer churn spike last quarter—need board-ready explanation
events: Q1: competitor launched, Q2: support tickets up 40%, Q3: churn +15%
micro_ex.thesis: Competitor entry exposed support capacity gap; churn followed unresolved tickets, not feature gap
micro_ex.alt_narrative: Churn was feature-driven; support tickets were symptom not cause
micro_ex.fork_point: did churned customers cite support or features in exit surveys?

quick_check: Does every event have a timestamp and source?
Are motive attributions backed by cited evidence?
Does the narrative have a one-sentence thesis?
Have I documented at least one alternative narrative?
Is there an uncertainty register with gaps and assumptions?
Am I claiming explanation, not causal proof?
